abstract: Microsoft challenged the rules on competition and antitrust law. Now, it’s Google’s turn.
snippet: Microsoft challenged the rules on competition and antitrust law. Now, it’s Google’s turn.
lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, who walked away from full-time work at Microsoft last month, was perhaps the foremost applied economist of the second half of the 20th century.

headline.main: Google, Zen Master of the Market
headline.print_headline: Google, Zen Master Of The Market

abstract: Updated: Carl C. Icahn is claiming a new backer in his proxy fight at Yahoo: Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Carl C. Icahn is claiming a new backer in his proxy fight at Yahoo: Microsoft.

headline.main: Microsoft Is Icahn’s Ally in Pursuit of Yahoo

abstract: CNBC's David Faber discusses Carl Icahn's latest letter to shareholders, in which the billionaire says Microsoft may hold talks -- with a new board.
snippet: CNBC's David Faber discusses Carl Icahn's latest letter to shareholders, in which the billionaire says Microsoft may hold talks -- with a new board.
lead_paragraph: CNBC's David Faber discusses Carl Icahn's latest letter to shareholders, in which the billionaire says Microsoft may hold talks -- with a new board.

headline.main: Microsoft Backs Icahn in Yahoo Fight

abstract: Microsoft’s latest statement that it might or might not be interested in buying all or part of Yahoo if Yahoo’s shareholders replace the company’s board is either cunningly devious or deeply confused.
snippet: Microsoft’s latest statement that it might or might not be interested in buying all or part of Yahoo if Yahoo’s shareholders replace the company’s board is either cunningly devious or deeply confused.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is either cunningly devious or deeply confused. Those are the only conclusions I can come to after reading the muddled statement that Microsoft put out Monday morning in response to Carl C. Icahn’s latest letter to Yahoo shareholders.
